textBeforeTable: Word Order   Word Order Present Perfect             fail (V) – lose strength, become weak   The project has received $27,000,000 to date. The Leaning Tower of Pisa has been closed for ten years. (passive verb - past perfect tense) Engineers have gradually reduced the lean by 14 centimeters so far. Their goal is 45 centimeters. It has been ten years since the last tourist saw the view from the top of the Tower of Pisa. The Tower of Pisa has leaned to the south since its third story was added in 1274.  (emphasis on duration) Use present perfect to focus on the duration of a past action (possibly ongoing). HAVING DURATION The tower was reopened in 2001. Officials closed the tower during the 1980s. The soil foundation failed under the tower in 1185. Builders added a third story in 1185. Construction started in 1173. (emphasis on completion) Use past tense to report that an action happened sometime in
textAfterTable: *A tag question can also occur with a negative main sentence and a positive final question: The tower hasn't stood there for long, has it? (doubtful question)   Related pages: Auxiliary Verbs, Past Participle Forms.       Perfect Forms AUXILIARY + NEXT FORM TYPE PRES PAST PERFECT MODAL ⇒ PLAIN FORM — will, would, may, might,can, could, shall, should, ought     Charlie will ⇒ have raised his hand by then. (future perfect) Charlie would ⇒ have raised his hand. (conditional perfect) PERFECT ⇒ PAST PARTICIPLE — has, have, had   Charlie has ⇒ raised his hand. Charlie had ⇒ raised his hand. Charlie had ⇒ raised his hand. (same as past) PROGRESSIVE  ⇒ GERUND-PARTICIPLE — is / are, was / were, been      Charlie has been ⇒ raising his hand. PASSIVE ⇒ PAST PARTICIPLE — is / are, was / were, been            Charlie's hand has been ⇒raised. Charlie's hand had been ⇒raised. Also see
